nodes.text: What is the cause of disposal?
This may be caused by an issue with the battery. Would you still like to extract this part?
What type of battery does this laptop have?

steps.action: Flip the laptop over and remove all screws on the bottom cover.
Pry up and remove the bottom panel.
Locate the battery and remove the screws securing it.
Carefully unplug the battery cable from the motherboard.
Lift the battery straight out of its bay.
Slide the latch(es) on the bottom of the laptop to the unlocked position.
Grip the exposed battery edge and pull it out of its compartment.

nodes.text: If the battery type is different (e.g., proprietary pack), consult the device’s service manual or look for visible release mechanisms before attempting removal.

instructions.step: Tape battery terminals or place each battery in a separate plastic bag.
Bring to a designated hazardous-waste or electronics recycling drop-off.
⚠️ WARNING: Never dispose of lithium-ion batteries in regular trash bins!

nodes.text: Overheating may be caused by a cooling/fan issue. Would you still like to extract the fan assembly?

steps.action: Remove base screws and pry off the bottom cover.
Unscrew the fan/heat-sink mounting screws.
Unplug the fan’s power cable from the motherboard.
Lift out the fan and heatsink assembly.

instructions.step: Separate metal and plastic parts; take to a certified e-waste recycler.

nodes.text: Is the HDD connected via a ribbon-cable with a flip-up locking flap?

steps.action: Flip up the locking flap on the cable connector to release it.
Remove mounting screws, then slide the drive out.
Remove the battery and open the HDD access door.
Slide the drive out by pulling its connector tab.
Open the cover to expose the M.2 slot.
Unscrew the standoff, lift the SSD at an angle, and slide it out.
Remove chassis screws and unplug SATA cables.
Remove drive mounting screws, then slide the SSD from its bay.

nodes.text: Is the RAM module held in by spring clips?

steps.action: Push side clips outward; the RAM pops up at 45°.
Pull the module straight out of its slot.

nodes.text: This RAM is soldered to the board—requires specialized tools; extraction may not be possible.
Would you like to extract the Wi-Fi card?

steps.action: Remove the service door and locate the mini-PCIe wireless card.
Unscrew the mounting screw and lift off antenna leads.
Slide the card out at a slight angle.

instructions.step: Recycle the PCB and metal components at a certified e-waste center.
